To evaluate this statement, we will use only a quote from the Constitution of the Czech Republic. Specifically, Article 68 , which states:

“(1) The Government is responsible to the Chamber of Deputies.

(2) The Prime Minister shall be appointed by the President of the Republic and, upon his proposal, shall appoint the other members of the Government and entrust them with the management of ministries or other offices.

(3) The Government shall appear before the Chamber of Deputies within thirty days of its appointment and request a vote of confidence.

(4) If the newly appointed government does not gain the confidence of the Chamber of Deputies, the procedure shall be as set out in paragraphs 2 and 3. If the government thus appointed also fails to gain the confidence of the Chamber of Deputies, the President of the Republic shall appoint the Prime Minister on the proposal of the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies.

It is precisely the fourth paragraph of the aforementioned article in the Constitution that describes that in the event of a vote of no confidence being cast on the first attempt, the same procedure is followed again. However, if a vote of no confidence is cast on the second attempt, a third attempt follows, during which the power to select the Prime Minister lies with the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies.

Let us add that this constitutional procedure gives the President of the Republic considerable room for discretion. In particular, the Constitution does not dictate to the President who should be appointed Prime Minister in each attempt to form a government. As a rule, this is the chairman of the party that won the election, but as Miloš Zeman mentions in a verified interview, the coalition potential of individual parliamentary parties also plays a role. Let us recall the parliamentary elections in 2010, when the ČSSD won, but President Klaus instead of Bohuslav Sobotka entrusted the formation of the government to the chairman of the second ODS, Petr Nečas, whom he subsequently appointed Prime Minister.

A similar case occurred in 2013 after the fall of the Nečas government, when the then Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies Miroslava Němcová had 101 parliamentary signatures in support of a possible new government, but President Zeman instead tasked Jiří Rusnok with forming a caretaker government and subsequently appointed him prime minister.

Even in the second attempt to appoint a prime minister who will form a government with confidence, there is no stipulation as to who should be appointed, especially that it should be the “second in line.” In 2018, for example, President Zeman appointed Andrej Babiš as prime minister even after his government failed to win confidence in the Chamber of Deputies.

However, it is not certain how they calculated this 380 billion, because the former Minister of Finance Alena Schillerová herself later mentioned 300 billion in an interview on Czech Television, while in a second interview she spoke about 330 billion.

In addition to the Minister's words, the last official calculation of tax reliefs was from 2018, when, according to estimates by the Ministry of Finance (MF), the total value was over 500 billion crowns. The total tax relief is calculated from tax reliefs for personal income tax, corporate income tax and value added tax. According to the document (.pdf, p. 1) Quantification of tax reliefs in the Czech Republic for 2018, which was published as an annex to the Fiscal Outlook of the Ministry of Finance, the total tax reliefs in 2018 amounted to 520 billion CZK (.pdf, p. 5).

At the same time, however, there is no (.pdf, p. 1) uniform methodology for calculating these reliefs and no other restrictive rules for the form of tax relief analysis are given. The difference in the estimate of the Ministry of Finance and Alena Schillerová may therefore be caused by a different methodology.

The state budget deficit should amount to 500 billion crowns this year according to the State Budget Act, but this plan is unlikely to be fulfilled. The state budget ended with a deficit of 401.5 billion crowns at the end of November, and it can therefore be assumed that the resulting deficit for 2021 will not be much higher. The aforementioned 380 billion crowns almost reach this year's estimated deficit.

Miloš Zeman is therefore correct in stating that he spoke about tax exemptions in the past in the Chamber of Deputies and even mentioned the amount of 380 billion crowns at that time. This sum does not correspond to the estimates of the former Minister of Finance or the estimates of the Ministry of Finance from 2018. Although they differ significantly, Miloš Zeman's 380 billion is between these estimates, which also do not have a uniform methodology. We therefore assess his statement as true with reservations.

For context, let us add that a tax relief is a measure (.pdf, p. 5) that is an advantage for the taxpayer in the form of lower or later tax payments compared to the situation where such a measure would not be included in the law. The reason for introducing a tax relief may be to support other public policies (for example, reducing taxes for taxpayers whose economic activity the state wants to support), achieving greater efficiency of the tax system (for example, exempting taxpayers with relatively low or zero incomes), or a combination of both.

Tax reliefs include, for example, tax exemptions, items reducing the tax base, items reducing the tax, reduced tax rates, etc. More specifically, for personal income tax, tax-exempt items include, for example, income in the form of awards in the field of culture , income in the form of scholarships from the state budget or from university funds.
